title: 112_hr1638
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dollar Bill Act of 2011". Congress acknowledges that the Federal Reserve System has been delegated the power to regulate the value of US and foreign currency, but notes that the value of the US dollar has significantly decreased and become unstable. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has not provided a stable value for the US dollar. The value of the United States dollar has become unstable, which hinders economic growth by increasing capital costs, risks for investments, and corporate income tax rates. This instability also reduces the real earnings of American workers and the value of financial assets. The unstable dollar increases capital costs, investment risks, and corporate income tax rates. It also reduces real earnings, financial asset value, pension plans, and retirement accounts. Additionally, it damages the US's economic and political standing globally, causing anxiety and uncertainty in financial markets and the public. SEC. 3. DIRECTIVES TO THE BOARD OF GOVERNORS OF THE FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System is directed to make the value of the U.S. dollar equal to the price of gold on the COMEX exchange and maintain it at that level. They are also instructed to use banking and regulatory powers to ensure stable financial markets during and after the transition. SEC. 4. TAX DEPRECIATION. Effective January 1, 2011, entities can expense 100 percent of capital investment for tax purposes in the year of investment. SEC. 5. DIRECTIVE TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET OFFICE. SEC. 5. DIRECTIVE TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET OFFICE. The Congressional Budget Office will calculate the impact on Federal revenues on a present value basis, similar to Social Security Trustees' calculations, considering first-year expensing of capital investment and higher returns on business investments. SEC. 6. CONFLICT OF LAWS PROVISION. In case of conflict with the Full Employment and Balanced Growth Act of 1978, this Act supersedes. SEC. 7. REMOVAL OF FEDERAL RESERVE BANK AUTHORITY TO PAY EARNINGS ON RESERVES. SEC. 7. REMOVAL OF FEDERAL RESERVE BANK AUTHORITY TO PAY EARNINGS ON RESERVES. Amendment to the Federal Reserve Act prohibits Federal Reserve banks from paying earnings on reserves.
